revision.text:
The '''Prandtl lifting-line theory'''<ref>Anderson, John D. (2001), ''Fundamental of aerodynamics'', McGraw-Hill, Boston. {{ISBN|0-07-237335-0}}. p360</ref> is a mathematical model that predicts lift distribution over a three-dimensional wing based on its geometry. It is also known as the '''Lanchester–Prandtl wing theory.'''<ref>{{cite book | title=Aerodynamics for Engineering Students |author1=Houghton, E. L. |author2=Carpenter, P.W. | edition=5th | year=2003 | editor=Butterworth Heinmann | isbn=0-7506-5111-3 }}</ref>
The theory was expressed independently<ref>{{cite book | title=Aerodynamics: Selected Topics in the Light of their Historical Development | author=[[Theodore von Kármán|Kármán, Theodore von]] | year=1954 | editor=Cornell University Press (reproduced by Dover in 2004) | isbn=0-486-43485-0 }}</ref> by [[Frederick W. Lanchester]] in 1907,<ref>{{cite book | title=Aerodynamics | author=[[Frederick W. Lanchester|Lanchester, Frederick W.]] | year=1907 | editor=Constable }}</ref> and by [[Ludwig Prandtl]] in 1918–1919<ref>{{cite book | title=Tragflügeltheorie | author=[[Ludwig Prandtl|Prandtl, Ludwig]] | year=1918 | editor=Königliche Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Göttingen }}</ref> after working with [[Albert Betz]] and [[Max Munk]].
In this model, the vortex loses strength along the whole wingspan because it is shed as a vortex-sheet from the trailing edge, rather than just at the wing-tips.<ref>[[Ira H. Abbott|Abbott, Ira H.]], and Von Doenhoff, Albert E., ''Theory of Wing Sections'', Section 1.4</ref><ref>Clancy, L.J., ''Aerodynamics'', Section 8.11</ref>
==Introduction== [[File:Lift distribution over a three-dimensional wing (1).svg|thumb|An unrealistic lift distribution that neglects three-dimensional effects]] [[File:Lift distribution over a three-dimensional wing (2).svg|thumb|A lift distribution as observed over a (finite) trapezoidal wing]] On a three-dimensional, finite wing, lift over each wing segment (local lift per unit span, <math>l</math> or <math>\tilde L</math>) does not correspond simply to what two-dimensional analysis predicts. Instead, this local amount of lift is strongly affected by the lift generated at neighboring wing sections.
It is difficult to predict analytically the overall amount of lift that a wing of given geometry will generate. The lifting-line theory yields the lift distribution along the span-wise direction, <math>\tilde L_{(y)}</math> based only on the wing geometry (span-wise distribution of chord, airfoil, and twist) and flow conditions (<math>\rho</math>, <math>V_\infty</math>, <math>\alpha_\infty</math>).
==Principle== The lifting-line theory applies the concept of [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] and the [[Kutta–Joukowski theorem]],
:<math>\tilde L_{(y)} = \rho V \Gamma_{(y)}</math>
so that instead of the ''lift'' distribution function, the unknown effectively becomes the distribution of circulation over the span, <math>\Gamma_{(y)}</math>.
{{Gallery |width=300 |align=center |File:Lifting line theory illustration (1).svg|The lift distribution over a wing can be modeled with the concept of [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] |File:Lifting line theory illustration (2).svg|[[Horseshoe vortex|A vortex is shed downstream]] for every span-wise change in lift }}
Modeling the (unknown and sought-after) local lift with the (also unknown) local circulation allows us to account for the influence of one section over its neighbors. In this view, any span-wise change in lift is equivalent to a span-wise change of circulation. According to [[Helmholtz's theorems]], a vortex filament cannot begin or terminate in the air. Any span-wise ''change in lift'' can be modeled as [[Horseshoe vortex|the shedding of a vortex filament down the flow]], behind the wing.
This shed vortex, whose strength is the derivative of the (unknown) local wing circulation distribution, <math>{\operatorname{d}\Gamma\over\operatorname{d}y}</math>, influences the flow left and right of the wing section.
{{Gallery |width=300 |align=center |lines=3 |File:Lifting line theory illustration (3).svg|The shed vortex can be modeled as a vertical velocity distribution |File:Lifting line theory illustration (4).svg|The upwash and downwash induced by the shed vortex can be computed at each neighbor segment. }}
This sideways influence (upwash on the outboard, downwash on the inboard) is the key to the lifting-line theory. Now, if the ''change'' in lift distribution is known at given lift section, it is possible to predict how that section influences the lift over its neighbors: the vertical induced velocity (upwash or downwash, <math>\omega_i</math>) can be quantified using the velocity distribution within a [[vortex]], and related to a change in effective angle of attack over neighboring sections.
In mathematical terms, the local induced change of angle of attack <math>\alpha_i</math> on a given section can be quantified with the integral sum of the downwash induced by every other wing section. In turn, the integral sum of the lift on each downwashed wing section is equal to the (known) total desired amount of lift.
This leads to an [[integro-differential equation]] in the form of <math>L_{total} = \rho V_\infty \int_{tip}^{tip} \Gamma_{(y)} \operatorname{d}y</math> where <math>\Gamma_{(y)}</math> is expressed solely in terms of the wing geometry and its own span-wise variation, <math>{\operatorname{d}\Gamma_{(y)}\over\operatorname{d}y}</math>. The solution to this equation is a function, <math>\Gamma_{(y)}</math>, that accurately describes the circulation (and therefore lift) distribution over a finite wing of known geometry.
==Derivation== (Based on.<ref>[http://web.aeromech.usyd.edu.au/aero/liftline/liftline.pdf Sydney University's Aerodynamics for Students (pdf)]</ref>)
Nomenclature: *<math> \ \Gamma </math> is the [[Circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] over the entire wing (m²/s) *<math> \ C_L </math> is the 3D [[lift coefficient]] (for the entire wing) *<math> \ AR </math> is the [[Aspect ratio (wing)|aspect ratio]] *<math> \ \alpha_\infty </math> is the freestream [[angle of attack]] (rad) *<math> \ V_\infty </math> is the freestream velocity (m/s) *<math> \ C_{D_i} </math> is the drag coefficient for [[Lift-induced drag|induced drag]] *<math> \ e </math> is the [[Oswald efficiency number|planform efficiency factor]]
The following are all functions of the wings span-wise station <math>y</math> (i.e. they can all vary along the wing) *<math> \ C_l </math> is the 2D [[lift coefficient]] (units/m) *<math> \ \gamma </math> is the 2D circulation at a section (m/s) *<math> \ c </math> is the [[Chord (aircraft)|chord length]] of the local section *<math> \ \alpha_{geo} </math> is the local change in angle of attack due to geometric twist of the wing *<math> \ \alpha_0 </math> is zero-lift angle of attack of that section (depends on the airfoil geometry) *<math> \ C_{l_\alpha} </math> is the 2D lift coefficient slope (units/m⋅rad, and depends on airfoil geometry, see [[Thin airfoil theory]]) *<math> \ \alpha_i </math> is change in angle of attack due to [[downwash]] *<math> \ w_i </math> is the local downwash velocity
To derive the model we start with the assumption that the circulation of the wing varies as a function of the spanwise locations. The function assumed is a Fourier function. Firstly, the coordinate for the spanwise location <math>y</math> is transformed by <math> y = scos{\theta}</math>, where y is spanwise location, and s is the semi-span of the wing.
[[File:Prandtl-lifting-line-coordinate-change.PNG]]
and so the circulation is assumed to be:
<math> \Gamma(y) = \Gamma(\theta) = \gamma = 4sV_\infty \sum_n{A_n \sin(n\theta}) \qquad (1)</math>
Since the circulation of a section is related the <math> C_l </math> by the equation:
<math>C_l= \frac{2 \gamma}{V_\infty c} \qquad (2)</math>
but since the coefficient of lift is a function of angle of attack:
<math>C_l = C_{l_\alpha}(\alpha_\infty + \alpha_{geo} - \alpha_0 - \alpha_i) \qquad (3)</math>
hence the vortex strength at any particular spanwise station can be given by the equations:
<math> \gamma = \frac{1}{2} V_\infty c C_{l_\alpha}(\alpha_\infty + \alpha_{geo} - \alpha_0 - \alpha_i) \qquad (4)</math>
This one equation has two unknowns: the value for <math> \gamma </math> and the value for <math> \alpha_i </math>. However, the downwash is purely a function of the circulation only. So we can determine the value <math> \alpha_i </math> in terms of <math> \Gamma(y) </math>, bring this term across to the left hand side of the equation and solve. The downwash at any given station is a function of the entire shed vortex system. This is determined by integrating the influence of each differential shed vortex over the span of the wing.
Differential element of circulation:
<math> d\Gamma = 4 s V_\infty \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}n A_n \cos(n\theta) \qquad (5)</math>
Differential downwash due to the differential element of circulation (acts like half an infinite vortex line):
<math> dw_i = \frac{d\Gamma}{4\pi r} \qquad (6)</math>
The integral equation over the span of the wing to determine the downwash at a particular location is:
<math> w_i = \int_{-s}^s \frac{1}{y-y_0} d\Gamma \qquad (7)</math>
After appropriate substitutions and integrations we get:
<math> w_i = V_\infty \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{n A_n \sin(n \theta)}{\sin(\theta)} \qquad (8)</math>
And so the change in angle attack is determined by ([[Small-angle approximation|assuming small angles]]):
<math> \alpha_i = \frac{w_i} {V_\infty} \qquad (9) </math>
By substituting equations 8 and 9 into RHS of equation 4 and equation 1 into the LHS of equation 4, we then get:
<math> 4 s V_\infty \sum_{n=1}^\infty A_n \sin(n \theta) = \frac{1}{2} V_\infty c C_{l_\alpha}\left[\alpha_\infty + \alpha_{geo} - \alpha_0 - \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{n A_n \sin(n \theta)}{\sin(\theta)} \right] \qquad (10) </math>
After rearranging, we get the series of simultaneous equations:
<math> \sum_{n=1}^\infty A_n \sin(n \theta) \bigg( \sin(\theta) + \frac{n C_{l \alpha} c}{8 s} \bigg) = \frac{C_{l \alpha} c}{8 s} \sin(\theta) (\alpha_\infty + \alpha_{geo} - \alpha_0) \qquad (11) </math>
By taking a finite number of terms, equation 11 can be expressed in matrix form and solved for coefficients A. Note the left-hand side of the equation represents each element in the matrix, and the terms on the RHS of equation 11 represent the RHS of the matrix form. Each row in the matrix form represents a different span-wise station, and each column represents a different value for n.
Appropriate choices for <math> \theta </math> are as a linear variation between <math> (0 , \pi ) </math>. Note that this range does not include the values for 0 and <math> \pi </math>, as this leads to a singular matrix, which can't be solved.
==Lift and drag from coefficients== The lift can be determined by integrating the circulation terms:
<math> \text{Lift} = \rho V_\infty \int_{-s}^s \Gamma (y) \cos{(\alpha_i(y))} dy \approx \rho V_\infty \int_{-s}^s \Gamma (y) dy </math>
which can be reduced to:
<math> C_L = \pi A\!R A_1 </math>
where <math> A_1 </math> is the first term of the solution of the simultaneous equations shown above.
The induced drag can be determined from
<math>\text{Drag}_\text{induced} = \rho V_\infty \int_{-s}^s \Gamma (y) \sin{(\alpha_i(y))} dy \approx \rho V_\infty \int_{-s}^s \Gamma (y) \alpha_i(y) dy</math>
which can also be reduced to:
<math> C_{D_{\text{induced}}} = \pi A\!R \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n A_n^2 </math>
where <math> A_n </math> are all the terms of the solution of the simultaneous equations shown above.
Moreover, this expression may be arranged as a function of <math> C_L </math> in the following way :
<math> C_{D_{\text{induced}}} = \pi A\!R A_1^2 + \pi A\!R \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n A_n^2 </math>
<math> C_{D_{\text{induced}}} = \pi A\!R A_1^2 * \frac{\pi A\!R}{\pi A\!R} + \pi A\!R \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n A_n^2 * \frac{\pi A\!R A_1^2}{\pi A\!R A_1^2} </math>
<math> C_{D_{\text{induced}}} = \frac{\pi^2 A\!R^2 A_1^2}{\pi A\!R} + \frac{\pi^2 A\!R^2 A_1^2}{\pi A\!R}* \frac{\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n A_n^2}{A_1^2} </math>
<math> C_{D_{\text{induced}}} = \frac{C_L^2}{\pi A\!R}(1+\frac{\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n A_n^2}{A_1^2}) = \frac{C_L^2}{\pi A\!R e}</math>
where
<math> \delta = \frac{\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n A_n^2}{A_1^2} </math>
<math> e = \frac{1}{1+\delta} </math> is the [[Oswald efficiency number#Comparison with span efficiency factor|span efficiency factor]]
==Symmetric wing== For a symmetric wing, the even terms of the series coefficients are identically equal to 0, and so can be dropped.
==Rolling wings== When the aircraft is rolling, an additional term can be added that adds the wing station distance multiplied by the rate of roll to give additional angle of attack change. Equation 3 then becomes:
<math>C_l = C_{l_{\alpha}}\left(\alpha_{\infty} + \alpha_{geo} - \alpha_0 - \alpha_i + \frac{p y}{s}\right) \qquad (3)</math>
where *<math> \ p </math> is the rate of roll in rad/sec,
Note that y can be negative, which introduces non-zero even coefficients in the equation that must be accounted for.
==Control deflection== The effect of ailerons can be accounted by simply changing <math> \alpha_0 </math> term in Equation 3. For non-symmetric controls such as ailerons the <math> \alpha_0 </math> term changes on each side of the wing.
==Elliptical wings== For an elliptical wing with no twist, with:
<math> y(\theta) = s \cos(\theta) </math>
The chord length is given as a function of span location as:
<math> c(\theta) = c_{root} \sin(\theta) </math>
Also,
<math> e = 1 </math>
This yields the famous equation for the elliptic induced drag coefficient:
<math> C_{D_{induced}} = \frac{C_L^2}{\pi A\!R} </math>
where *<math> s </math> is the value of the wing span, *<math> y(\theta) </math> is the position on the wing span, and *<math> c(\theta) </math> is the chord.
==Useful approximations== A useful approximation is that :<math> \ C_{L} = C_{l_\alpha} \left( \frac{\text{AR}}{\text{AR}+2} \right) \alpha </math><ref>Ref?</ref> where *<math> \ C_{\text{L}} </math> is the 3D [[lift coefficient]] for elliptical circulation distribution, *<math> \ C_{l_\alpha} </math> is the 2D lift coefficient slope (see [[Thin Airfoil Theory]]), *<math> \ \text{AR} </math> is the [[Aspect ratio (wing)|aspect ratio]], and *<math> \ \alpha </math> is the [[angle of attack]] in radians.
The theoretical value for <math> \ C_{l_\alpha} </math> is 2<math> \pi </math>. Note that this equation becomes the [[Thin Airfoil Theory|thin airfoil]] equation if ''AR'' goes to infinity.<ref>[http://www.aerospaceweb.org/question/aerodynamics/q0136.shtml Aerospace Web's explanation of lift coefficient]</ref>
As seen above, the lifting-line theory also states an equation for [[induced drag]]:.<ref>Abbott, Ira H., and Von Doenhoff, Albert E., ''Theory of Wing Sections'', Section 1.3</ref><ref>Clancy, L.J., ''Aerodynamics'', Equation 5.7</ref> :<math> \ C_{D_i} = \frac{{C_L}^2}{\pi \text{AR} e} </math> where *<math> \ C_{D_i} </math> is the drag coefficient for induced drag, *<math> \ C_L </math> is the 3D [[lift coefficient]], and *<math> \ \text{AR} </math> is the [[Aspect ratio (wing)|aspect ratio]]. *<math> \ e </math> is the planform efficiency factor (equals 1 for elliptical circulation distribution, and usually tabulated for other distributions).
==Limitations of the theory== The lifting line theory does not take into account the following: * [[Compressible flow]] * [[Viscous flow]] * [[Swept wing]]s * [[Low aspect ratio]] wings * [[Unsteady flow]]s
==See also== * [[Horseshoe vortex]] * [[Thin Airfoil Theory]] * [[Vortex lattice method]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Clancy, L.J. (1975), ''Aerodynamics'', Pitman Publishing Limited, London. {{ISBN|0-273-01120-0}} * Abbott, Ira H., and Von Doenhoff, Albert E. (1959), ''Theory of Wing Sections'', Dover Publications Inc., New York. Standard Book Number 486-60586-8
[[Category:Aerodynamics]]
